content: Derek Nguyen, a master’s candidate at the Bren School, graduated from the University of California, Santa Barbara in 2019 with a Bachelor of Arts in Environmental Studies. During his undergraduate career, Derek conducted research on dry groundwater wells in the Western 17 states. His research helped to measure other locations potentially experiencing impacts from groundwater depletion. Derek also served as the Food Recovery Project Coordinator of UCSB’s Sustainability Program where he developed and implemented food recovery programs on-campus to reduce food waste and food insecurity within the student body. Derek is currently an intern at the Goleta Water District where he assists the Engineering Department in collecting and analyzing water quality samples from various water zones within the district. Derek wants to specialize in Water Resources Management with afocus in Environmental Data Science to learn more about water use efficiency and demand management. He aspires to promote equity and resiliency of water systems especially in underserved communities.

Flexibility This feature can be used for publishing content such as:
 Online courses Project or software documentation Tutorials  The courses folder may be renamed. For example, we can rename it to docs for software/project documentation or tutorials for creating an online course.
Delete tutorials To remove these pages, delete the courses folder and see below to delete the associated menu link.
Update site menu After renaming or deleting the courses folder, you may wish to update any [[main]] menu links to it by editing your menu configuration at config/_default/menus.toml.
For example, if you delete this folder, you can remove the following from your menu configuration:
[[main]] name = "Courses" url = "courses/" weight = 50  Or, if you are creating a software documentation site, you can rename the courses folder to docs and update the associated Courses menu configuration to:
[[main]] name = "Docs" url = "docs/" weight = 50  Update the docs menu If you use the docs layout, note that the name of the menu in the front matter should be in the form [menu.X] where X is the folder name. Hence, if you rename the courses/example/ folder, you should also rename the menu definitions in the front matter of files within courses/example/ from [menu.example] to [menu.<NewFolderName>].
summary: Learn how to use Academic's docs layout for publishing online courses, software documentation, and tutorials.

Introduction Here we explore the a dataset provided by, Google Earth Engine, that provides various environmental and climatic data on countries throughout the world. For this particular project, variables observed are: annual mean temperature, annual mean rainfall, accessibility to cities, tree canopy cover, cloudiness, elevation, and cropland cover.
world_env <- read_csv(here::here("csv", "world_env_vars.csv")) world_env_tidy <- world_env %>% clean_names() %>% select(cropland_cover, tree_canopy_cover, accessibility_to_cities, elevation, rain_mean_annual, temp_mean_annual, cloudiness) %>% drop_na() world_env_pca <- prcomp(world_env_tidy, scale = TRUE)  Summary  Mean annual rainfall and tree canopy cover is most positively correlated. This correlation makes sense because rainfall provides nutrients for trees and tree canopy cover would grow. Mean annual rainfall is also positively correlated with cloudiness. This seems valid because cloudy days mean higher potential for rainfall. Mean annual temperature and cropland cover are inversely correlated. Mean annual temperature and elevation are inversely correlated. This makes sense because as elevation increases, temperature goes down and vice versa.

snowshoe_sex <- snowshoe_tidy %>% select(date, sex, weight) %>% filter(sex %in% c("f", "m")) %>% group_by(sex) %>% drop_na() summary_sex <- snowshoe_sex %>% summarize(mean_weight = mean(weight, na.rm = TRUE), sd_weight = sd(weight, na.rm = TRUE), standard_error = (sd(weight)/sqrt(length(weight))), sample_size = n()) ggplot(data = summary_sex, aes(x = sex, y = mean_weight)) + geom_beeswarm(data = snowshoe_sex, aes(x = sex, y = weight, color = sex), show.legend = FALSE, size = 1, alpha = 0.5) + geom_errorbar(data = summary_sex, aes(ymin = mean_weight - sd_weight, ymax = mean_weight + sd_weight), width = 0.2, color = "firebrick") + geom_point(data = summary_sex, aes(x = sex, y = mean_weight)) + labs(x = "Sex", y = "Mean Weight (grams)") + scale_y_continuous(expand = c(0,0)) + scale_x_discrete(labels = c("Female", "Male")) + theme_minimal() table_sex <- summary_sex %>% mutate(sex = case_when( sex == "f" ~ "Female", sex == "m" ~ "Male" )) %>% mutate_if(is.numeric, round, 2) kable(table_sex, col.names = c("Sex", "Mean Weight", "SD Weight", "Standard Error", "Sample Size")) %>% kable_styling(bootstrap_options = "striped", full_width = F, position = "center") %>% row_spec(c(1:2), color = "navy") %>% add_header_above(c("Snowshoe Hare Sex Metrics" = 5))   Snowshoe Hare Sex Metrics     Sex  Mean Weight  SD Weight  Standard Error  Sample Size      Female  1365.16  347.45  8.94  1511    Male  1349.94  305.73  9.15  1117     Graph AGE

INTRODUCTION The California Spiny Lobster, Panulirus interruptus, is a decapod crustacean that has a habitat that spans from the Monterey Bay, California to Baja California, Mexico (Sea Grant California 2019). The California Spiny Lobster is one of the largest spiny lobsters in the world with males capable of growing up to three feet long and weighing up to 26 pounds. Fishing of California Spiny Lobster is regulated by the California Department of Fish and Wildlife and has an open season from October through March (California Department of Fish and Wildlife and Sea Grant California 2019).
Data on California Spiny Lobsters has been collected off of the coast of Santa Barbara by the Santa Barbara Coastal Term Ecological Research (SBC LTER), an interdisciplinary program based at the University of California, Santa Barbara Marine Science Institute. SB LTER has been collecting data on size, abundance, and fishing pressure of California Spiny Lobster at five study sites along the Santa Barbara Channel since 2012. Two of the sites, Naples and Isla Vista, are within Marine Protected Areas (MPAs) and three of the sites, Arroyo Quemado, Mohawk, and Carpinteria, are otuside of MPAs (Reed D. 2019). In an effort to investigate lobster size differences or similarities between the study sites within an MPA and those outside of an MPA, this report will analyze lobster sizes between the years of 2012 and 2018 and across the five different study sites.
Figure 1: California Spiny Lobster Underwater. California Spiny Lobster walking on the sea floor. (Credit: Vice)
Figure 2: Cooked California Spiny Lobster. A cooked California Spiny Lobster on a dish with butter and lemons. (Credit: Sea Grant California)

 DATA AND METHODS Data for Spiny Lobster abundance and location from 2012 - 2018 were collected and provided by SBC LTER. Data on California Spiny Lobster size and abundance (individuals) is collected annually by divers in the late summer before the start of the fishing season at five SBC LTER long term kelp forest study sites with two sites within MPAs: Naples and Isla Vista, and three outside of MPAs: Arroyo Quemado, Mohawk, and Carpinteria. The variables of interest and analyzed for the report were lobster abundance for each year, lobster size in millimeters, and site locations categorized within or outside of MPA’s, called MPA’s and non-MPAs, respectively. Mean lobster size distributions (mm) was compared for year 2012 vs 2018 and for site location, MPA vs non-MPA by two-sample, two-sided t-tests (α = 0.05 throughout) as well as applying cohen’s d index to evaluate effect size between groups. All analyses and figures were prepared using R Software Version 1.2.1335.

 RESULTS A: Changes in annual lobster abundance (counts) by site ggplot(lobster_ysite, aes(x = year, y = total_count, fill = site), show.legend = FALSE) + geom_col(aes(fill = MPA), alpha = 0.9) + facet_wrap(~site) + theme_dark() + scale_y_continuous(expand = c(0,0), lim = c(0,1000)) + scale_x_continuous(expand = c(0,0)) + labs(x = "Year", y = "Total Lobster Observations", fill = "Site") Figure 4: Annual Lobster Abundance. Lobster counts at the Arroyo Quemado, Carpinteria, Isla Vista, Mohawk, and Naples study sites between the years of 2012 - 2018. Data: Reed D. 2019.
California Spiny Lobster abundance data was compared annually, from 2012 to 2018, across each of the five sites (Figure 4). Spiny Lobster abundance at the two sites with MPAs, Isla Vista and Naples,show an increase in Spiny Lobster abundance collected over time. This increase can be an indicator of MPA’s significant purpose in preserving California Spiny Lobster populations since these predators play an important role in maintaining ecological processes of kelp forests. California Spiny Lobster counts collected within sites outside of MPA’s are consistently low, with the exception of Carpinteria in 2017 (where total counts = 705) but then dropped significantly in 2018. This lack of protection for the non-MPA sites can be an indicator that there is a lot of influence by human activity.
 B. Lobster size distribution shifts in 2012 and 2018. lobster_size <- lobster_tidy %>% select(year, site, size_mm) %>% filter(year %in% c(2012, 2018)) %>% mutate(year = as.character(year)) lobster_size$site[lobster_size$site == "AQUE"] <- "Arroyo Quemado" lobster_size$site[lobster_size$site == "CARP"] <- "Carpinteria" lobster_size$site[lobster_size$site == "IVEE"] <- "Isla Vista" lobster_size$site[lobster_size$site == "MOHK"] <- "Mohawk" lobster_size$site[lobster_size$site == "NAPL"] <- "Naples" ggplot(data = lobster_size) + geom_histogram(aes(x = size_mm, fill = site, alpha = 0.9, color = site), binwidth = 8, show.legend = FALSE) + facet_grid(year~site, scales = "free") + theme_dark() + scale_y_continuous(expand = c(0,0)) + scale_x_continuous(expand = c(0,0)) + labs(x = "Lobster Size (mm)", y = "Total Lobster Observations") Figure 5: Lobster Size Distributions Across 5 Study Sites Lobster size distribution of observations across the MPA Sites: Isla Vista & Naples; and non-MPA Sites: Arroyo Quemado, Carpinteria, Mohawk for the years 2012 and 2018. Data: Reed D. 2019.
California Spiny Lobster counts collected are significantly higher for 2018 (n_MPA2018 = 1244, n_nonMPA = 561), than in 2012 (n_MPA = 32, n_nonMPA = 199), but both have minimum samples of over 30 observations, which is sufficient enough to compare across these groups. The proportion of size distribution for sites within MPA’s saw a comeback in larger lobster populations from 2012 to 2018, while sites outside MPA’s saw a decrease in larger lobster populations from 2012 to 2018. Smaller lobsters within MPA sites also experienced a population increase.
Although Mohawk is outside of an MPA, it has a fairly symmetrical distribution of lobster size between 2012 and 2018. Mohawk may have unique physical features where human activity is not impacting the population as drammatically compared to the other sites not in MPA’s.
 C. Compare mean lobster sizes at MPA vs. non-MPA sites in 2012 and 2018. lobster_mean_size <- lobster_tidy %>% mutate(mpa = case_when( site %in% c("IVEE", "NAPL") ~ "MPA", site %in% c("AQUE", "MOHK", "CARP") ~ "non-MPA")) %>% filter(year %in% c(2012, 2018)) %>% select(year, site, size_mm, mpa) %>% group_by(year, mpa) lobster_size_table <- lobster_mean_size %>% summarize(mean = mean(size_mm, na.rm = TRUE), sd = sd(size_mm, na.rm = TRUE), sample_size = n()) %>% mutate_if(is.numeric, round, 1) Null Hypothesis: The mean size, in millimeters, of lobsters collected at MPA sites vs non-MPA sites are the same.
Alternate Hypothesis: The mean size, in millimeters, of lobsters collected at MPA sites vs non-MPA sites are not the same.
Table 1: Lobster Size Metrics Means, Standard Deviations, and Sample Sizes of the California Spiny Lobsters for the years 2012 and 2018 between the MPA and non-MPA Sites. Data: Reed D. 2019.
lobster_size_table %>% kable(col.names = c("Year", "MPA", "Mean (mm)", "Standard Deviation", "Sample Size")) %>% kable_styling(bootstrap_options = "striped", full_width = F, position = "center") %>% row_spec(c(1,3), color = "red") %>% row_spec(c(2,4), color = "black")   Year  MPA  Mean (mm)  Standard Deviation  Sample Size      2012  MPA  67.4  12.2  32    2012  non-MPA  74.9  12.4  199    2018  MPA  77.6  11.7  1244    2018  non-MPA  73.6  10.1  561     In 2012, lobster samples collected for MPA and non-MPA sites were far smaller than the lobster samples collected in 2018.
For non-MPA sites, lobster sizes decreased from 2012 to 2018 and for MPA sites, average lobster sizes increased overtime.
The small sample sizes for 2012 may be a factor in why the average sizes for the sites are smaller.
nonmpa_2012 <- lobster_mean_size %>% filter(year =="2012", mpa == "non-MPA") nonmpa_2018 <- lobster_mean_size %>% filter(year == "2018", mpa == "non-MPA") mpa_2012 <- lobster_mean_size %>% filter(year == "2012", mpa == "MPA") mpa_2018 <- lobster_mean_size %>% filter(year == "2018", mpa == "MPA") mean_mpa_2012 <- mean(mpa_2012$size_mm, na.rm = TRUE) mean_mpa_2018 <- mean(mpa_2018$size_mm, na.rm = TRUE) mean_nonmpa_2012 <- mean(nonmpa_2012$size_mm, na.rm = TRUE) mean_nonmpa_2018 <- mean(nonmpa_2018$size_mm, na.rm = TRUE) sd_mpa_2012 <- sd(mpa_2012$size_mm, na.rm = TRUE) sd_mpa_2018 <- sd(mpa_2018$size_mm, na.rm = TRUE) sd_nonmpa_2012 <- sd(nonmpa_2012$size_mm, na.rm = TRUE) sd_nonmpa_2018 <- sd(nonmpa_2018$size_mm, na.rm = TRUE) n_mpa_2012 <- sum(!is.na(mpa_2012$size_mm)) n_mpa_2018 <- sum(!is.na(mpa_2018$size_mm)) n_nonmpa_2012 <- sum(!is.na(nonmpa_2012$size_mm)) n_nonmpa_2018 <- sum(!is.na(nonmpa_2018$size_mm)) size_2012_ttest <- t.test(mpa_2012$size_mm, nonmpa_2012$size_mm, paired = FALSE) # If P value is lower than alpha (0.5), which it is, we reject the null hypothesis and confirm the alternative hypothesis as it indicates strong evidence against the null hypothesis. size_2012_d <- effsize::cohen.d(mpa_2012$size_mm, nonmpa_2012$size_mm, na.rm = TRUE) # Effect size is 0.61, which is a medium effect size, thus the difference can be noticed with some effort. size_2018_ttest <- t.test(mpa_2018$size_mm, nonmpa_2018$size_mm, paired = FALSE) # If P value is lower than alpha (0.5), which it is, we reject the null hypothesis and confirm the alternative hypothesis as it indicates strong evidence against the null hypothesis. size_2018_d <- effsize::cohen.d(mpa_2018$size_mm, nonmpa_2018$size_mm, na.rm = TRUE) # Effect size is 0.35, which is a small effect size, thus to notice the difference it would have to be studied. size_mpa_ttest <- t.test(mpa_2012$size_mm, mpa_2018$size_mm, paired = FALSE) # If P value is lower than alpha (0.5), which it is, we reject the null hypothesis and confirm the alternative hypothesis as it indicates strong evidence against the null hypothesis. size_mpa_d <- effsize::cohen.d(mpa_2012$size_mm, mpa_2018$size_mm, na.rm = TRUE) # Effect size is 0.87, which is a large effect size, thus the difference is easily noticeable. Cohen's D shows that the P value's rejection of the null hypothesis is easily noticeable. size_nonmpa_ttest <- t.test(nonmpa_2012$size_mm, nonmpa_2018$size_mm, paired = FALSE) # If P value is lower than alpha (0.5), which it is NOT, thus we fail to reject the null hypothesis as it indicates weak evidence against the null hypothesis. size_nonmpa_d <- effsize::cohen.d(nonmpa_2012$size_mm, nonmpa_2018$size_mm, na.rm = TRUE) # Effect size is 0.12, which is a small effect size, thus the difference between the samples is not easily noticeable. Cohen's D confirms that the uncertainty in the rejection of the null hypothesis, as indicated by the P value, is small. 
Lobster size differences between MPA and non-MPA sites for 2012 only The mean lobster sizes between the MPA (67.4) and non-MPA (75) sites in 2012 was 7.5 millimeters (mm). Between the MPA and non-MPA sites, the size difference is statistically significant (two-sided t-test, t(42.1) = -3.3, p = 0) and the effect size is moderate (Cohen’s d = -0.61). This indicates that between the MPA and non-MPA sites, the mean lobster size difference of 7.5mm is significant and moderately substantive.
 Lobster size differences between MPA and non-MPA sites for 2018 only The mean lobster sizes between the MPA (77.6) and non-MPA (74) sites in 2018 was 4.0 millimeters (mm). Between the MPA and non-MPA sites, the size difference is statistically significant (two-sided t-test, t(1239.5) = 7.3, p = 0) and the effect size is small (Cohen’s d = 0.35). This indicates that between the MPA and non-MPA sites, the mean lobster size difference of 4.0mm is significant and but not very substantive.
 Mean size differences in 2012 and 2018 for MPA Sites only The mean size of lobsters found within the MPA sites increased by 10.2 millimeters (mm) (from 67.4mm to 77.6mm) between 2012 and 2018. Between the two years, the size increase is statistically significant (two-sided t-test, t(32.5) = -4.7, p = 0) and the effect size is large (Cohen’s d = -0.87). This indicates that from 2012 to 2018, the mean lobster size increase at MPA sites of 10.2mm was significant and substantive.
 Mean size differences in 2012 and 2018 for non-MPA sites only Mean sizes of lobsters found within the three non-MPA sites decreased by 1.3mm (from 74.9 mm to 73.6mm) between 2012 and 2018. Between the two years, the size increase is not statistically significant (two-sided t-test, t(296) = 1.3, p = 0) and the effect size is small (Cohen’s d = 0.12) This indicates that from 2012 to 2018, the mean lobster size decrease at non-MPA sites of 1.3mm was not significant nor substantive.

   SUMMARY  Lobster populations within MPA sites increased overtime while lobster populations outside MPA sites were consistently at lower levels (Figure 4). The difference between mean sizes for lobsters within MPA sites between 2012 and 2018 was significant and substantive. There is a substantive difference in lobster sizes between MPA sites and non-MPA sites for 2012 and 2018.  
 REFERENCES California Department of Fish & Wildlife and Sea Grant Foundation. California Spiny Lobster: fishing and life history information. https://nrm.dfg.ca.gov/FileHandler.ashx?DocumentID=36321&inline. Accessed 11/17/2019.
Clarissa Wei. 2016. Vice. Why We Don’t Eat California Spiny Lobsters (Even Though They Taste Better). https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/gvk5kq/why-we-dont-eat-california-spiny-lobsters-even-though-they-taste-better. Photo by Kate Mansury. Accessed 11/17/2019.
Reed D. 2019. SBC LTER: Reef: Abundance, size and fishing effort for California Spiny Lobster (Panulirus interruptus), ongoing since 2012. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/a593a675d644fdefb736750b291579a0. Dataset accessed 10/30/2019.
Sea Grant California. California Seafood Profiles, About, Spiny Lobster: Panulirus interruptus. https://caseagrant.ucsd.edu/seafood-profiles/spiny-lobster. Accessed 11/17/2019.

Academic is designed to give technical content creators a seamless experience. You can focus on the content and Academic handles the rest.
Highlight your code snippets, take notes on math classes, and draw diagrams from textual representation.
On this page, you’ll find some examples of the types of technical content that can be rendered with Academic.
Examples Code Academic supports a Markdown extension for highlighting code syntax. You can enable this feature by toggling the highlight option in your config/_default/params.toml file.
```python import pandas as pd data = pd.read_csv("data.csv") data.head() ```  renders as
import pandas as pd data = pd.read_csv("data.csv") data.head()  Math Academic supports a Markdown extension for $\LaTeX$ math. You can enable this feature by toggling the math option in your config/_default/params.toml file.
To render inline or block math, wrap your LaTeX math with $...$ or $$...$$, respectively.
Example math block:
$$\gamma_{n} = \frac{ \left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T \left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |} {\left \|\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n-1}) \right \|^2}$$  renders as
$$\gamma_{n} = \frac{ \left | \left (\mathbf x_{n} - \mathbf x_{n-1} \right )^T \left [\nabla F (\mathbf x_{n}) - \nabla F (\mathbf x_{n-1}) \right ] \right |}{\left |\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n}) - \nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n-1}) \right |^2}$$
Example inline math $\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})$ renders as $\nabla F(\mathbf{x}_{n})$.
Example multi-line math using the \\ math linebreak:
$$f(k;p_0^*) = \begin{cases} p_0^* & \text{if }k=1, \\ 1-p_0^* & \text {if }k=0.\end{cases}$$  renders as
$$f(k;p_0^*) = \begin{cases} p_0^* & \text{if }k=1, \
1-p_0^* & \text {if }k=0.\end{cases}$$
Diagrams Academic supports a Markdown extension for diagrams. You can enable this feature by toggling the diagram option in your config/_default/params.toml file or by adding diagram: true to your page front matter.
An example flowchart:
```mermaid graph TD A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round) B --> C{Decision} C -->|One| D[Result 1] C -->|Two| E[Result 2] ```  renders as
graph TD A[Hard] -->|Text| B(Round) B --> C{Decision} C -->|One| D[Result 1] C -->|Two| E[Result 2]  An example sequence diagram:
```mermaid sequenceDiagram Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you? loop Healthcheck John->>John: Fight against hypochondria end Note right of John: Rational thoughts! John-->>Alice: Great! John->>Bob: How about you? Bob-->>John: Jolly good! ```  renders as
sequenceDiagram Alice->>John: Hello John, how are you? loop Healthcheck John->>John: Fight against hypochondria end Note right of John: Rational thoughts! John-->>Alice: Great! John->>Bob: How about you? Bob-->>John: Jolly good!  An example Gantt diagram:
```mermaid gantt section Section Completed :done, des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08 Active :active, des2, 2014-01-07, 3d Parallel 1 : des3, after des1, 1d Parallel 2 : des4, after des1, 1d Parallel 3 : des5, after des3, 1d Parallel 4 : des6, after des4, 1d ```  renders as
gantt section Section Completed :done, des1, 2014-01-06,2014-01-08 Active :active, des2, 2014-01-07, 3d Parallel 1 : des3, after des1, 1d Parallel 2 : des4, after des1, 1d Parallel 3 : des5, after des3, 1d Parallel 4 : des6, after des4, 1d  An example class diagram:
```mermaid classDiagram Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool <<interface>> Class01 Class09 --> C2 : Where am i? Class09 --* C3 Class09 --|> Class07 Class07 : equals() Class07 : Object[] elementData Class01 : size() Class01 : int chimp Class01 : int gorilla class Class10 { <<service>> int id size() } ```  renders as
classDiagram Class01 <|-- AveryLongClass : Cool <<interface>> Class01 Class09 --> C2 : Where am i? Class09 --* C3 Class09 --|> Class07 Class07 : equals() Class07 : Object[] elementData Class01 : size() Class01 : int chimp Class01 : int gorilla class Class10 { <<service>> int id size() }  An example state diagram:
```mermaid stateDiagram [*] --> Still Still --> [*] Still --> Moving Moving --> Still Moving --> Crash Crash --> [*] ```  renders as
stateDiagram [*] --> Still Still --> [*] Still --> Moving Moving --> Still Moving --> Crash Crash --> [*]  Todo lists You can even write your todo lists in Academic too:
- [x] Write math example - [x] Write diagram example - [ ] Do something else  renders as
 Write math example Write diagram example Do something else  Tables Represent your data in tables:
| First Header | Second Header | | ------------- | ------------- | | Content Cell | Content Cell | | Content Cell | Content Cell |  renders as
   First Header Second Header     Content Cell Content Cell   Content Cell Content Cell    Asides Academic supports a shortcode for asides, also referred to as notices, hints, or alerts. By wrapping a paragraph in {{% alert note %}} ... {{% /alert %}}, it will render as an aside.
{{% alert note %}} A Markdown aside is useful for displaying notices, hints, or definitions to your readers. {{% /alert %}}  renders as
 A Markdown aside is useful for displaying notices, hints, or definitions to your readers.   Icons Academic enables you to use a wide range of icons from Font Awesome and Academicons in addition to emojis.
Here are some examples using the icon shortcode to render icons:
{{< icon name="terminal" pack="fas" >}} Terminal {{< icon name="python" pack="fab" >}} Python {{< icon name="r-project" pack="fab" >}} R  renders as

Create or upload a Jupyter notebook Run the following commands in your Terminal, substituting <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER> and <SHORT-POST-TITLE> with the file path to your Academic website folder and a short title for your blog post (use hyphens instead of spaces), respectively:
mkdir -p <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER>/content/post/<SHORT-POST-TITLE>/ cd <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER>/content/post/<SHORT-POST-TITLE>/ jupyter lab index.ipynb  The jupyter command above will launch the JupyterLab editor, allowing us to add Academic metadata and write the content.
Edit your post metadata The first cell of your Jupter notebook will contain your post metadata ( front matter).

--- title: My post's title date: 2019-09-01 # Put any other Academic metadata here... ---  Edit the metadata of your post, using the documentation as a guide to the available options.
To set a featured image, place an image named featured into your post’s folder.

Convert notebook to Markdown jupyter nbconvert index.ipynb --to markdown --NbConvertApp.output_files_dir=.  Example This post was created with Jupyter. The orginal files can be found at https://github.com/gcushen/hugo-academic/tree/master/exampleSite/content/post/jupyter

R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.
You can embed an R code chunk like this:
summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.:19.0 3rd Qu.: 56.00 ## Max. :25.0 Max. :120.00 fit <- lm(dist ~ speed, data = cars) fit ## ## Call: ## lm(formula = dist ~ speed, data = cars) ## ## Coefficients: ## (Intercept) speed ## -17.579 3.932  Including Plots You can also embed plots. See Figure 1 for example:
par(mar = c(0, 1, 0, 1)) pie( c(280, 60, 20), c('Sky', 'Sunny side of pyramid', 'Shady side of pyramid'), col = c('#0292D8', '#F7EA39', '#C4B632'), init.angle = -50, border = NA )  Figure 1: A fancy pie chart.
